Several of the rebels who fought at the Battle of the Alamo were slave owners. However, it's worth noting that not all of the rebels were slave owners, and the motivations for fighting in the battle were complex and varied.

Among the slave-owning rebels who fought at the Alamo were James Bowie and William Barret Travis, both of whom were prominent figures in the Texas Revolution. Bowie was a land speculator who had made his fortune in Louisiana and Texas and owned several slaves. Travis was a lawyer and newspaper editor who had come to Texas in search of economic opportunities and owned at least one slave.

Davy Crockett, another famous figure who fought at the Alamo, did not own slaves and was a vocal opponent of slavery. However, it's worth noting that he had previously supported the institution of slavery and had owned slaves earlier in his life.

Overall, while some of the rebels who fought at the Alamo were slave owners, the issue of slavery was not the primary motivation for their fight for independence from Mexico. Instead, the rebels were driven by a range of factors, including a desire for economic and political independence and a belief in the principles of liberty and self-determination.
